   This is a 63 y/o M who has continued AMS to point where not
   communicating at all; with hx Hepatitis C cirrhosis, s/p PEA arrest,
   body cooling and rewarming, with Fusobacterium sepsis covering with IV
   Pen G until [**2145-1-21**].
   .
   # Mental Status: With slowly resolving delerium prior to this event,
   and now with unclear hypoxic insult to brain. GCS of [**6-27**] on admission
   to ICU.  Considering head CT to evaluate for anoxic brain injury
   post-cooling.  Neuro eval for possible seizure. EEG neg for seizure,
   severe encephalopathy likely in setting of sedation.  LP done earlier
   that was negative gram stain/culture, no whites, negative HSV PCR. Back
   to pre-code MS per wife. CT scan did not show any focal lesions.
   - patient is following commands, off propofol sedation, psych saw
   patient on [**1-15**] and felt that the patient was very unlikely to have had
   NMS and recommended seroquel to be used for agitation.
   - starting seroquel today
   - plan for MRI today
   - continue max dose of lactulose and rifaximin
   .
   # bleeding from trach site- Procedure done [**1-13**], 8-0 Portex .lost
   150cc. Patient was given giving 2u platelets, given 1u FFP after the
   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .
   # Respiratory/Ventilation: Pt re-intubated [**1-11**] secondary to
   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed
   evidence of pulmonary edema. Patient getting trach [**1-13**] in OR. Patient
   completed treatment for empire HAP for 5day with vanc/zosyn starting
   [**1-7**]. Stopped vanc [**1-14**], continuing zosyn until sensitivities of
   fusobacterium.
   - giving Lasix 40mg IV with goal -2L
   - tolerating trach collar today very well
   .
   # Fusobacterium sepsis: Will treat for two-week course, awaiting
   sensitivities on Fusobacterium -> likely responsive to penicillin. Dx
   on [**1-7**], will need 14d course until [**1-21**]. Covered with zosyn until
   sensitivies obtained.
   - surveillance blood cxs NTD
   - complete course of PCN until [**1-21**]
   .
   # thrombocytopenia
 [**1-1**] platlets 171, now 44. Switched from H2 to
   PPI. Considering HIT vs. splenic sequestration
   - obtaining smear
   - plts starting to improve slightly after switch
   .
   # Resolved Renal Failure: Unclear etiology, likely combination of ATN
   in the setting of code and HRS.  Renal following given concern for HRS.
   Off albumin, mitodrine and octreotide
   - renal function stable
   - f/u renal and liver recs
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely hypovolemic hypernatremia in the setting of
   recent ATN and current HRS.  Corrected [**1-11**], free water deficit ~ 2-3L.
   - switching antibiotics to be made with D5W
   - cont free water flushes q3 hr through G tube
   .
   # Cardiac: CE's trended post-arrest. Echo hyperdynamic, no cardiogenic
   shock. CK and Trop trended down
   - will consider repeat echo
   .
   # Cirrhosis: Hep C Cirrhosis, with concern for HRS.
   - pre-code mental status likely related to encephalopathy v. delirium
   - titrate up lactulose
   - liver recs -> non suitable for tx at this point, in the very small
   chance that pt improves could possibly be candidate in the future
   .
   # s/p Shock/PEA Arrest: After PEA, was initially hemodynamically stable
   but has had episodes of hypotension non-responsive to IVF boluses,
   levofed started, currently off. Echo showed no evidence of cardiogenic
   shock. s/p cooling and rewarming. Trended cardiac enzymes, came down
   and no evidence of cardiogenic shock on rewarmed echo.
   # Parotid mass. Incidental finding of L parotid mass on MRI, 1.6cm. --
   Will require ENT followup as outpt.
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: s/p arrest [**12-21**] to tissue hypoxia.  Lactates now
   normalized, now resolved.
   # Access: PIV, Central Line

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of hepatitis C cirrhosis who experienced a cardiopulmonary arrest and was successfully resuscitated. He was subsequently diagnosed with Fusobacterium sepsis, for which he received intravenous penicillin G until January 21st. The patient required intubation due to respiratory distress and was placed on mechanical ventilation. He underwent tracheostomy placement and is now tolerating the tracheostomy collar well. The patient also presented with thrombocytopenia, which has slightly improved after switching from H2 to PPI. His renal function has improved, and he no longer shows signs of renal failure. He was treated for hypernatremia by correcting the free water deficit and switching antibiotics to be made with D5W. The patient's cardiac enzymes trended down, and there is no evidence of cardiogenic shock on rewarmed echo. He has cirrhosis with concern for hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). An incidental finding of a left parotid mass on MRI will require ENT follow-up as an outpatient. The patient's metabolic acidosis has resolved. He has multiple lines in place, including a multi-lumen central line and arterial line. The patient is currently on full code status and is being kept in the ICU for ongoing care.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of hep C cirrhosis, small hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), and previous cervical laminectomy. He was admitted for falls and underwent laminectomy but did not recover motor skills. He had a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest one week ago due to a mucous plug and required intubation. The patient has been experiencing episodic agitation, requiring an increase in propofol. He has a history of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) and is currently on seroquel instead of haldol.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature of 38.1 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 163/66 mmHg to 191/81 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on a tracheostomy mask with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)/pressure support ventilation (PSV) mode.

Fluid balance shows an intake of 4,016 mL with outputs totaling 5,960 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 1,944 mL. The patient has received multiple antibiotics including piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin, and penicillin G potassium.

Physical examination reveals clear breath sounds, warm skin, and no muscle wasting. Neurological assessment indicates that the patient is not attentive, does not follow simple commands, responds to noxious stimuli, and movement and tone are not assessed.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count within normal range, slightly low platelet count, elevated creatinine level, and normal electrolyte levels. Blood cultures grew fusobacterium. Other lab values, including liver function tests and blood gases, are provided in the note.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Encephalopathy: The patient is well on lactulose and seroquel for agitation. Consider MRI to work up anoxic brain injury.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is doing well on a tracheostomy mask.
3. Acute renal failure: Improved.
4. HCV cirrhosis: ICU care will focus on nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the provided information, potential medical complications that can arise include worsening encephalopathy, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, hepatic complications related to HCV cirrhosis, and infections such as VAP or DVT.

   - patient not responding to pain or consistently following commands,

   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .

   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, who experienced a post-cardiac arrest syndrome and was resuscitated. He has been in the ICU since then and has been diagnosed with various medical complications. The patient's current conditions include acute mental status changes, respiratory distress requiring reintubation, bleeding from the tracheostomy site, Fusobacterium sepsis, thrombocytopenia, resolved renal failure, hypernatremia, cardiac issues post-arrest, cirrhosis with concern for hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), parotid mass, metabolic acidosis, and prolonged ICU stay.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute mental status changes: The patient has shown fluctuating levels of consciousness and confusion, which may be due to hypoxic insult to the brain, encephalopathy, or delirium.
2. Respiratory distress and need for reintubation: The patient's respiratory system is compromised, leading to repeated episodes of respiratory distress. He requires ongoing mechanical ventilation support through the tracheostomy.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 63 y/o M who has continued AMS to point where not
   communicating at all; with hx Hepatitis C cirrhosis, s/p PEA arrest,
   body cooling and rewarming, with Fusobacterium sepsis covering with IV
   Pen G until [**2145-1-21**].
   .
   # Mental Status: With slowly resolving delerium prior to this event,
   and now with unclear hypoxic insult to brain. GCS of [**6-27**] on admission
   to ICU.  Considering head CT to evaluate for anoxic brain injury
   post-cooling.  Neuro eval for possible seizure. EEG neg for seizure,
   severe encephalopathy likely in setting of sedation.  LP done earlier
   that was negative gram stain/culture, no whites, negative HSV PCR. Back
   to pre-code MS per wife. CT scan did not show any focal lesions.  MRI
   ([**1-16**]) was unremarkable.
   - patient is following commands, off propofol sedation, psych saw
   patient on [**1-15**] and felt that the patient was very unlikely to have had
   NMS and recommended seroquel to be used for agitation.
   - continue max dose of lactulose and rifaximin
   .
   # bleeding from trach site- Procedure done [**1-13**], 8-0 Portex .lost
   150cc. Patient was given giving 2u platelets, given 1u FFP after the
   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .
   # Respiratory/Ventilation: Pt re-intubated [**1-11**] secondary to
   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed
   evidence of pulmonary edema. Patient getting trach [**1-13**] in OR. Patient
   completed treatment for empire HAP for 5day with vanc/zosyn starting
   [**1-7**]. Stopped vanc [**1-14**], continuing zosyn until sensitivities of
   fusobacterium.
   - giving Lasix 40mg IV with goal -2L
   - tolerating trach collar very well
   .
   # Fusobacterium sepsis: Will treat for two-week course, awaiting
   sensitivities on Fusobacterium -> likely responsive to penicillin. Dx
   on [**1-7**], will need 14d course until [**1-21**]. Covered with zosyn until
   sensitivies obtained.
   - surveillance blood cxs NTD
   - complete course of PCN until [**1-21**]
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 [**1-1**] platlets 171, now 44. Switched from H2 to
   PPI. Considering HIT vs. splenic sequestration
   - f/u smear
   - plts starting to improve slightly after switch
   .
   # Resolved Renal Failure: Unclear etiology, likely combination of ATN
   in the setting of code and HRS.  Renal following given concern for HRS.
   Off albumin, mitodrine and octreotide
   - renal function stable
   - f/u renal and liver recs
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely hypovolemic hypernatremia in the setting of
   recent ATN and current HRS.  Corrected [**1-11**], free water deficit ~ 2-3L.
   - switching antibiotics to be made with D5W
   - cont free water flushes q3 hr through G tube
   .
   # Cardiac: CE's trended post-arrest. Echo hyperdynamic, no cardiogenic
   shock. CK and Trop trended down
   - will consider repeat echo
   .
   # Cirrhosis: Hep C Cirrhosis, with concern for HRS.
   - pre-code mental status likely related to encephalopathy v. delirium
   - titrate up lactulose
   - liver recs -> non suitable for tx at this point, in the very small
   chance that pt improves could possibly be candidate in the future
   .
   # s/p Shock/PEA Arrest: After PEA, was initially hemodynamically stable
   but has had episodes of hypotension non-responsive to IVF boluses,
   levofed started, currently off. Echo showed no evidence of cardiogenic
   shock. s/p cooling and rewarming. Trended cardiac enzymes, came down
   and no evidence of cardiogenic shock on rewarmed echo.
   # Parotid mass. Incidental finding of L parotid mass on MRI, 1.6cm. --
   Will require ENT followup as outpt.
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: s/p arrest [**12-21**] to tissue hypoxia.  Lactates now
   normalized, now resolved.
   # Access: PIV, Central Line
   .
   # FEN: TF running at goal, 60cc/hr
   .
   # Prophylaxis: holding HSQ since elevated PTT, PPI
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Wife is HCP -> will readdress long-term goals re:
   long-term prognosis
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now.
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, who experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and subsequent hypotension. The patient was cooled and rewarmed, and treated for Fusobacterium sepsis. He has ongoing mental status changes, respiratory distress requiring reintubation, thrombocytopenia, resolved renal failure, hypernatremia, cardiac issues, and parotid mass. The patient is currently in the ICU and receiving mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient had Fusobacterium sepsis, which was treated with intravenous Pen G until January 21st. It is important to monitor for any signs of recurrent sepsis.
2. Delirium: The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, and he is currently non-communicative. Delirium may persist or worsen, and close monitoring of his mental status is necessary.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient required reintubation due to respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions. He is currently on mechanical ventilation. Weaning off the ventilator may be challenging, and further respiratory support may be needed.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is significantly low. Continued monitoring of platelet levels and bleeding risks is essential. Transfusion of platelets or other blood products may be required to maintain adequate clot

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 63-year-old man with a history of HCV cirrhosis who experienced a postoperative cardiac arrest and required ventilation. He has been unresponsive with poor motor score (MS) and has shown desaturation episodes. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.1 C (100.6 F), heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 145/64 to 175/134 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on a tracheostomy mask with supplemental oxygen. The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, warm skin, and soft non-tender abdomen. Neurological examination shows no follow-up commands or response to noxious stimuli. 

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.6 K/uL, elevated lactate levels, elevated liver enzymes, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 59. Other lab values are within normal limits. Imaging studies are unremarkable.

The patient has been diagnosed with Fusobacterium sepsis and is receiving Penicillin G. Efforts are being made to limit sedation and provide bolus nutrition. The patient's hypernatremia is being addressed by repleting free water while diuresing. The patient's thrombocytopenia has improved. The patient's code status is

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 63 y/o M who has continued AMS to point where not
   communicating at all; with hx Hepatitis C cirrhosis, s/p PEA arrest,
   body cooling and rewarming, with Fusobacterium sepsis covering with IV
   Pen G until [**2145-1-21**].
   .
   # Mental Status: With slowly resolving delerium prior to this event,
   and now with unclear hypoxic insult to brain. GCS of [**6-27**] on admission
   to ICU.  Considering head CT to evaluate for anoxic brain injury
   post-cooling.  Neuro eval for possible seizure. EEG neg for seizure,
   severe encephalopathy likely in setting of sedation.  LP done earlier
   that was negative gram stain/culture, no whites, negative HSV PCR. Back
   to pre-code MS per wife. CT scan did not show any focal lesions.  MRI
   ([**1-16**]) was unremarkable.
   - patient not responding to pain or consistently following commands,
   off propofol sedation, psych saw patient on [**1-15**] and felt that the
   patient was very unlikely to have had NMS and recommended seroquel to
   be used for agitation.
   - d/c propofol (still intermittently using)
   - continue max dose of lactulose and rifaximin
   .
   # bleeding from trach site- Procedure done [**1-13**], 8-0 Portex .lost
   150cc. Patient was given giving 2u platelets, given 1u FFP after the
   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .
   # Respiratory/Ventilation: Pt re-intubated [**1-11**] secondary to
   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed
   evidence of pulmonary edema. Patient getting trach [**1-13**] in OR. Patient
   completed treatment for empiric HAP for 5day with vanc/zosyn starting
   [**1-7**].
    - giving Lasix 40mg IV with goal -2L
   - tolerating trach collar very well
   .
   # Fusobacterium sepsis: Will treat for two-week course, awaiting
   sensitivities on Fusobacterium -> likely responsive to penicillin. Dx
   on [**1-7**], will need 14d course until [**1-21**]. Covered with zosyn until
   sensitivies obtained.
   - surveillance blood cxs NTD
   - complete course of PCN on [**1-21**]
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 [**1-1**] platelets 171, slowly declining. Switched
   from H2 to PPI. Considering HIT vs. splenic sequestration
   - f/u smear
   - no current evidence of DIC
   - plts starting to improve slightly after switch from H2 to PPI
   .
   # Resolved Renal Failure: Unclear etiology, likely combination of ATN
   in the setting of code and HRS.  Renal following given concern for HRS.
   Off albumin, mitodrine and octreotide
   - renal function stable
   - f/u renal and liver recs
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely hypovolemic hypernatremia in the setting of
   recent ATN and current HRS.  Corrected [**1-11**], free water deficit ~ 2-3L.
   - switching antibiotics to be made with D5W
   - increase free water boluses through G-tube
   .
   # Cardiac: CE's trended post-arrest. Echo hyperdynamic, no cardiogenic
   shock. CK and Trop trended down
   - will consider repeat echo
   .
   # Cirrhosis: Hep C Cirrhosis, with concern for HRS.
   - pre-code mental status likely related to encephalopathy v. delirium
   - titrate up lactulose
   - liver recs -> non suitable for tx at this point, in the very small
   chance that pt improves could possibly be candidate in the future
   .
   # s/p Shock/PEA Arrest: After PEA, was initially hemodynamically stable
   but has had episodes of hypotension non-responsive to IVF boluses,
   levofed started, currently off. Echo showed no evidence of cardiogenic
   shock. s/p cooling and rewarming. Trended cardiac enzymes, came down
   and no evidence of cardiogenic shock on rewarmed echo.
   # Parotid mass. Incidental finding of L parotid mass on MRI, 1.6cm. --
   Will require ENT followup as outpt.
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: s/p arrest [**12-21**] to tissue hypoxia.  Lactates now
   normalized, now resolved.
   # Access: PIV, Central Line
   .
   # FEN: TF running at goal, 60cc/hr
   .
   # Prophylaxis: holding HSQ since elevated PTT, PPI
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Wife is HCP -> will readdress long-term goals re:
   long-term prognosis
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now.
   ICU Care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, who experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and subsequent cooling and rewarming. The patient has been in the ICU since then.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Mental status: The patient is not communicating at all, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) ranging from 6 to 27 on admission to the ICU. There is a possibility of anoxic brain injury due to hypoxic insult during the arrest.
2. Bleeding from tracheostomy site: The patient experienced bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which was addressed by replacing the tracheostomy tube and administering blood products.
3. Respiratory/ventilation: The patient was reintubated due to respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and is tolerating the tracheostomy collar well.
4. Fusobacterium sepsis: The patient is being treated for fusobacterium sepsis, which was diagnosed on January 7th. He will receive a two-week course of antibiotics until January 21st.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is slowly declining. HIT vs. splenic sequestration is being considered as possible causes. The patient is being followed up with a smear and no evidence of disseminated intravascular

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, who experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, subsequent hypothermia and rewarming, and was diagnosed with Fusobacterium sepsis. The patient has had multiple complications including delirium, bleeding from the tracheostomy site, respiratory distress leading to reintubation, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, hypernatremia, cardiac issues, liver disease, parotid mass, metabolic acidosis, and an incidental finding of a left parotid mass on MRI. The patient's condition remains critical and requires ongoing ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Delirium: The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, and he is still agitated despite being off propofol sedation.
2. Bleeding: The patient experienced bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which required intervention and blood product transfusion. There was also a concern for posterior pharynx bleed, but it was not found during the ENT evaluation.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient required reintubation due to respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions. It is unlikely that he will tolerate extubation.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a declining platelet count, which needs to be monitored and managed appropriately.
5. Renal Failure: The patient had unclear etiology renal failure

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 63 y/o M who has continued AMS to point where not
   communicating at all; with hx Hepatitis C cirrhosis, s/p PEA arrest,
   body cooling and rewarming, with Fusobacterium sepsis covering with IV
   Pen G until [**2145-1-21**].
   .
   # Mental Status: With slowly resolving delerium prior to this event,
   and now with unclear hypoxic insult to brain. GCS of [**6-27**] on admission
   to ICU.  Considering head CT to evaluate for anoxic brain injury
   post-cooling.  Neuro eval for possible seizure. EEG neg for seizure,
   severe encephalopathy likely in setting of sedation.  LP done earlier
   that was negative gram stain/culture, no whites, negative HSV PCR. Back
   to pre-code MS per wife. CT scan did not show any focal lesions.  MRI
   ([**1-16**]) was unremarkable.
   - patient not consistently following commands, off propofol sedation,
   psych saw patient on [**1-15**] and felt that the patient was very unlikely
   to have had NMS and recommended seroquel to be used for agitation
   will uptitrate per Psych recs
 standing Seroquel TID
   - propofol off
   - increase lactulose to 60mg q2hr for stool ouput goal of 1000cc and
   cont rifaximin
   - Will check thyroid studies and ammonia as cause of AMS
   .
   # bleeding from trach site- Procedure done [**1-13**], 8-0 Portex .lost
   150cc. Patient was given giving 2u platelets, given 1u FFP after the
   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved, tr blood at site, but controlled
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .
   # Respiratory/Ventilation: Pt re-intubated [**1-11**] secondary to
   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed
   evidence of pulmonary edema. Patient getting trach [**1-13**] in OR. Patient
   completed treatment for empiric HAP for 5day with vanc/zosyn starting
   [**1-7**].
   - tolerating trach collar very well
   .
   # Fusobacterium bacteremia: Will treat for two-week course, awaiting
   sensitivities on Fusobacterium -> likely responsive to penicillin. Dx
   on [**1-7**], will need 14d course until [**1-21**].
   - surveillance blood cxs NTD
   - complete course of PCN on [**1-21**]
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 [**1-1**] platelets 171, slowly declining. Switched
   from H2 to PPI. Considering HIT vs. splenic sequestration
   - no current evidence of DIC
   - plts stable after switch from H2 to PPI
   .
   # Resolved Renal Failure: Unclear etiology, likely combination of ATN
   in the setting of code and HRS.  Renal following given concern for HRS.
   Off albumin, mitodrine and octreotide
   - renal function stable
   - f/u renal and liver recs
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely hypovolemic hypernatremia in the setting of
   recent ATN and current HRS.  Corrected [**1-11**], free water deficit 3.5L on
   [**2145-1-18**]
   - increase free water boluses through G-tube to provide 3.5L by
   tomorrow PM
   .
   # Cardiac: CE's trended post-arrest. Echo hyperdynamic, no cardiogenic
   shock. CK and Trop trended down
   - will consider repeat echo
   .
   # Cirrhosis: Hep C Cirrhosis, with concern for HRS.
   - pre-code mental status likely related to encephalopathy v. delirium
   - titrate up lactulose
   - liver recs -> non suitable for tx at this point, in the very small
   chance that pt improves could possibly be candidate in the future
   .
   # s/p Shock/PEA Arrest: Now stable. After PEA, was initially
   hemodynamically stable but has had episodes of hypotension
   non-responsive to IVF boluses, levofed started, currently off. Echo
   showed no evidence of cardiogenic shock. s/p cooling and rewarming.
   Trended cardiac enzymes, came down and no evidence of cardiogenic shock
   on rewarmed echo.

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of Hepatitis C cirrhosis, who presented with multiple medical complications. He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, underwent cooling and rewarming, and was diagnosed with Fusobacterium sepsis. The patient required reintubation due to respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions. He also had bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which was controlled. The patient has thrombocytopenia, resolved renal failure, hypernatremia, cardiac issues, liver cirrhosis with concern for hepatorenal syndrome (HRS), parotid mass, metabolic acidosis, and multiple lines and tubes in place.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections due to his compromised immune system and prolonged ICU stay.
2. Bleeding: The patient had bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could be a concern if the clotting factors are not properly managed.
3. Respiratory Issues: The patient required reintubation and has difficulty handling secretions, which may indicate ongoing respiratory problems.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Liver Dysfunction: The patient has liver cirrhosis and concerns for HRS, which can lead to further complications such as encephalopathy and renal dysfunction.
6. Cardiac Issues:

The patient's mental status has been slowly improving, but there is ongoing confusion and delirium. The patient's respiratory status is stable with a tracheostomy in place, and he is tolerating the trach collar well. The patient is being treated for Fusobacterium bacteremia with a planned 14-day course of penicillin.

Hypernatremia has been corrected, and free water deficit is being managed with intravenous free water boluses. Thrombocytopenia is present, with platelet counts slowly declining, but the patient's platelet levels have stabilized after switching from H2 to PPI. Renal function has improved, and the patient is off albumin, midodrine, and octreotide.

   This is a 63 y/o M who has continued AMS to point where not
   communicating at all; with hx Hepatitis C cirrhosis, s/p PEA arrest,
   body cooling and rewarming, with Fusobacterium sepsis covering with IV
   Pen G until [**2145-1-21**].
   .
   # Mental Status: With slowly resolving delerium prior to this event,
   and now with unclear hypoxic insult to brain. GCS of [**6-27**] on admission
   to ICU.  Considering head CT to evaluate for anoxic brain injury
   post-cooling.  Neuro eval for possible seizure. EEG neg for seizure,
   severe encephalopathy likely in setting of sedation.  LP done earlier
   that was negative gram stain/culture, no whites, negative HSV PCR. Back
   to pre-code MS per wife. CT scan did not show any focal lesions.  MRI
   ([**1-16**]) was unremarkable.  Mental status is somewhat improved today.
   - off propofol sedation,
   - psych saw patient on [**1-15**] and felt that the patient was very unlikely
   to have had NMS and recommended seroquel for agitation (uptitrate per
   Psych recs
 standing Seroquel TID with prns)
   - lactulose increased to 60mg q4hr for stool ouput goal of 1000cc and
   cont rifaximin; ammonia not elevated
   - Thyroid studies wnl
   .
   # Respiratory/Ventilation: Pt re-intubated [**1-11**] secondary to
   respiratory distress and inability to handle secretions.  Unlikely to
   tolerate extubation given that underlying problem is inability to
   handle secretions which is unlikely to change. CXR from [**1-13**] showed
   evidence of pulmonary edema. Patient getting trach [**1-13**] in OR. Patient
   completed treatment for empiric HAP for 5day with vanc/zosyn starting
   [**1-7**].
   - tolerating trach collar very well
   .
   # Fusobacterium bacteremia: Will treat for two-week course, awaiting
   sensitivities on Fusobacterium -> likely responsive to penicillin. Dx
   on [**1-7**], will need 14d course until [**1-21**].
   - surveillance blood cxs NTD
   - complete course of PCN on [**1-21**]
   .
   # bleeding from trach site- Procedure done [**1-13**], 8-0 Portex .lost
   150cc. Patient was given giving 2u platelets, given 1u FFP after the
   procedure. ENT was consulted on [**1-14**] for concern of posterior pharynx
   bleed, which they did not find any evidence of.
   - bleeding has improved, tr blood at site, but controlled
   - ENT found small bite on back of tongue, but no evidence of posterior
   pharynx bleed
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely hypovolemic hypernatremia in the setting of
   recent ATN and current HRS.  Corrected [**1-11**], free water deficit 3.5L on
   [**2145-1-18**] and now corrected again as TF were held overnight except for FW
   boluses..
   - increase free water boluses through G-tube
   - will discuss with nutrition to see if there is a way to decrease
   sodium in TF or dilute TF to prevent hypernatremia
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia
 [**1-1**] platelets 171, slowly declining. Switched
   from H2 to PPI. Considering HIT vs. splenic sequestration
   - no current evidence of DIC
   - plts stable after switch from H2 to PPI
   .
   # Resolved Renal Failure: Unclear etiology, likely combination of ATN
   in the setting of code and HRS.  Renal following given concern for HRS.
   Off albumin, mitodrine and octreotide
   - renal function stable
   - f/u renal and liver recs
   .
   # Cardiac: CE's trended post-arrest. Echo hyperdynamic, no cardiogenic
   shock. CK and Trop trended down
   - will consider repeat echo
   .
   # Cirrhosis: Hep C Cirrhosis, with concern for HRS.
   - pre-code mental status likely related to encephalopathy v. delirium
   - lactulose increased
   - liver recs -> non suitable for tx at this point, in the very small
   chance that pt improves could possibly be candidate in the future
   .
   # s/p Shock/PEA Arrest: Now stable. After PEA, was initially
   hemodynamically stable but has had episodes of hypotension
   non-responsive to IVF boluses, levofed started, currently off. Echo
   showed no evidence of cardiogenic shock. s/p cooling and rewarming.
   Trended cardiac enzymes, came down and no evidence of cardiogenic shock
   on rewarmed echo.
   # Parotid mass. Incidental finding of L parotid mass on MRI, 1.6cm. --
   Will require ENT followup as outpt.
   .
   # Metabolic Acidosis: s/p arrest [**12-21**] to tissue hypoxia.  Lactates now
   normalized, now resolved.
   # Access: Central Line and A-line; will remove A-line today and request
   PICC placement.
   .
   # FEN: were stopped due to patient positioning, will try restarting
   today for goal, 60cc/hr
               Speech/swallow c/s for consideration of passy-muir valve.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: holding HSQ since elevated PTT, PPI
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Wife is HCP -> will readdress long-term goals re:
   long-term prognosis
   .
   # Disposition: ICU for now.  [**Month (only) 11**] be able to transition to floor vs.
   rehab soon.

- The patient's renal failure has resolved, but the cause is unclear. There is concern for HRS.
